author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Belarus Sprinter’s Defection Sheds Light on a Dictator’s Levers of Control
description: Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, and authoritarian leaders before him, have used sports as a propaganda tool. But defections have had a long history of puncturing their aura of invincibility.
content: When Belarusian Olympic officials came to Kristina Timanovskaya’s room after the sprinter complained publicly about her coaches, the head of the national team made it clear they had an order for her to return home — and it came from the top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Trump asks a judge to block the Treasury Department from giving his tax returns to Congress.
description: In a 37-page filing, Mr. Trump’s legal team picked up arguments that the Trump-era Justice Department had put forward in a bid to stonewall the congressional request.
content: Lawyers for President Donald J. Trump argued in a new court document on Wednesday that a House committee’s request to obtain six years of Mr. Trump’s tax returns should be blocked, portraying the effort as politically motivated and illegitimate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Teach Writing With The New York Times: Our 2021-22 Curriculum
description: A flexible, eight-unit program based on the real-world features found in newspapers, from editorials and reviews to personal narratives, profiles and podcasts.
content: What can the news, features, essays, interviews, photos, videos, podcasts and graphics in The New York Times teach your students about composing for a real audience? So much, we hope, that the units we detail below are just a beginning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: With Capitol Sit-In, Cori Bush Galvanized a Progressive Revolt Over Evictions
description: Refusing to move from the Capitol steps, the first-term congresswoman from St. Louis intensified pressure on the Biden administration and showed her tactics could yield results.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Cori Bush of Missouri was 20 the first time she was evicted, tossed out by a landlord after a violent fight with her boyfriend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: Climate Change Could Devastate Emperor Penguins, U.S. Officials Warn
description: The Fish and Wildlife Service announced a proposal on Tuesday to list the birds as a threatened species.
content: Climate change is threatening emperor penguins with extinction in much of their range, federal wildlife officials said on Tuesday as they announced a proposal to protect them under the Endangered Species Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: The comedian Amber Ruffin asks athletes: ‘Do you know you did an amazing job?’
description: Ruffin, who hosts her own show on Peacock, has added a twist to athletes’ post-match interviews.
content: Amber Ruffin, a comedian and the host of “The Amber Ruffin Show” on Peacock, NBC’s streaming platform, added a twist to post-match interviews with athletes as part of her on-the-ground coverage of the Games from Tokyo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman
title: After cajoling and threats, Pakistan is vaccinating a million people a day.
description: Pakistan reached a milestone in Covid vaccinations this week, health officials said: The number of people receiving shots surpassed one million a day.
content: Pakistan reached a milestone in Covid vaccinations this week, health officials said: The number of people receiving shots surpassed one million a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: The New York Times Reaches 8 Million Subscriptions
description: The company expects to end the year with about 8.5 million. In its quarterly results, it reported holding nearly $1 billion in cash.
content: The New York Times Company said in a statement announcing its quarterly earnings results on Wednesday that it had eight million subscriptions and expected to add as many this year as it did in 2019, when President Donald J. Trump dominated headlines and a pandemic had yet to melt the global economy. The company estimated that it will have 8.5 million paid print and digital subscriptions by the end of 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel reinstates some virus restrictions to avoid a full lockdown.
description: Mask-wearing and vaccination requirements will be expanded, travel rules will be tightened and more Israelis will be told to work from home, the government said.
content: With its population vaccinated against the coronavirus at a fast pace and only a handful of new cases being reported, Israel all but declared victory over the virus earlier this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Soraya Shockley, Clare Toeniskoetter, Jessica Cheung, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: Trouble in Tunisia
description: The North African nation was the darling of the Arab Spring. But has its 10-year experiment with democracy come to an end?
content: Tunisia was supposed to be the success story of the Arab Spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Nevin Harrison, 19, can win a rare American medal in canoeing.
description: TOKYO — When Nevin Harrison first tried canoe racing at age 12, becoming an Olympian was not the first thing on her mind. Staying out of the water was.
content: TOKYO — When Nevin Harrison first tried canoe racing at age 12, becoming an Olympian was not the first thing on her mind. Staying out of the water was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Subscription Buffet May Be Over
description: Spotify, YouTube and others are experimenting with changing their one-size-fits-all digital subscriptions.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: A Time of Challenge and Change: Writing Prompts to Help You Reflect
description: An ongoing list of questions to help teenagers document their lives during a time that will define their generation.
content: As part of the suite of resources we’re creating to help students document and reflect on their lives, we’ve rounded up a list we hope can provide instant inspiration. Here is a selection of  Student Opinion questions we’ve posed on our site since the pandemic first began to shut down schools in early 2020. We will continue to update this list through October, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Tensions Flare Again Along Israel-Lebanon Border
description: Militants in Lebanon fired rockets at Israel, which retaliated with artillery fire. Amid rising frictions in the region, Israeli officials hinted they would respond forcefully to recent escalations linked to Iran.
content: JERUSALEM — Militants in southern Lebanon fired rockets into Israel on Wednesday for the second time in two weeks, prompting the Israeli Army to retaliate first with artillery fire and later with airstrikes in a new flare-up after days of tension across the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: 13 Grilled Chicken Recipes That Aren’t Boring or Dry
description: It’s easy to overdo chicken on the grill, but these recipes promise tender, flavorful results.
content: Chicken is easily the most searched for ingredient on New York Times Cooking, and it stands to reason: It’s economical, it’s widely available, it’s better for the climate than other meats. And it’s endlessly adaptable, a blank canvas for all sorts of preparations and vibrant, delicious seasonings. In the cold weather months, that means cozy soups, braises and burnished roasts. But in the summer, grilling becomes the method of choice, as it gets you out of a hot kitchen, and adds a layer of fire-kissed flavor and texture to the otherwise mild-mannered meat. You can always salt the dickens out of chicken, grill it well and get tasty results, but if you’re looking for something a bit more exciting, here are 13 of our favorite grilled chicken recipes that will keep you busy and full through September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: With the eviction moratorium back in place, the Biden administration is racing to distribute aid.
description: The new evictions ban signed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is scheduled to expire on Oct. 3.
content: The reinstatement of the federal eviction moratorium on Tuesday came as a relief for progressives, but for White House officials it was just the starting gun of a 60-day sprint to distribute billions in rental aid, in a nerve-rattling race that could be stopped by the courts at any moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Theater to Stream: Offerings on the Fringe of Edinburgh Fringe
description: Other highlights include a project by Lisa Loeb, Dominique Morisseau’s “Detroit ’67” and a new production of “South Pacific.”
content: Like a lot of other events, the sprawling Edinburgh Festival Fringe did not happen last summer. At least it not physically: Many Edinburgh-related digital events sprouted in its stead. Fringe is back in person this year, but so are some of the streaming presenters, delivering the festival’s unruly, anything-goes vibe all over the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Semifinal matches loom for U.S. women’s soccer and beach volleyball.
description: Also on Thursday, the first golds in climbing and karate will be awarded.
content: TOKYO — After a comprehensive victory over Spain, the American men’s basketball team took the court on Thursday afternoon against Australia in a semifinal game. The winner will play for the gold medal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: You Should Resign, Governor Cuomo
description: New York’s governor has lost his credibility.
content: Last winter, after the first wave of accusations of sexual misconduct and harassment by Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York came to light, this board called for an investigation to run its course and for legal authorities to carry out the slow and careful work of separating allegations from evidence. At the same time, we questioned whether Mr. Cuomo could continue to serve as the state’s leader, given both the seriousness of the allegations and the collapse of political support among his allies in New York and Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: The Offspring’s drummer says he was dropped from the band over being unvaccinated.
description: “It has recently been decided that I am unsafe to be around, in the studio, and on tour,” Pete Parada said, citing medical reasons for not getting vaccinated.
content: Pete Parada, the drummer for the pop-punk band the Offspring, says his decision not to get a Covid-19 vaccination for medical reasons has cost him his job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below in the introductory article for this feature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sabin
title: How Liberals Can Attack From the Left — and Win
description: The “better” in Biden’s “Build Back Better” slogan is vital for success.
content: In the fall of 1965, Ralph Nader, then 31, published a blistering attack on the poor safety record of the American automobile. Tens of thousands of Americans were dying needlessly every year on the nation’s highways, and the blame lay with the federal government, Mr. Nader argued in his first book, “Unsafe at Any Speed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Democrats Seek $500 Billion in Climate Damages From Big Polluting Companies
description: Under a draft plan Democrats are circulating, the Treasury Department would tax a handful of the biggest emitters of planet-warming pollution to pay for climate change.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats in Congress want to tax Exxon, Chevron and a handful of other major oil and gas companies, saying the biggest climate polluters should pay for the floods, wildfires and other disasters that scientists have linked to the burning of fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Asanka Brendon Ratnayake
title: As Hikers Vanish, These Mountains Hold Tight to Their Mysteries
description: The high country of southern Australia is “remote and beautiful and unpredictable,” a place where visitors can be swallowed up without a sound.
content: MERRIJIG, Australia — A blanket of fog hanging before him, Lachlan Culican saddled up his horse one autumn morning and set off into the remote high country of southern Australia to find two campers gone missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: As hurricane season’s peak looms, experts issue an ‘above normal’ forecast.
description: We’re on top of the latest extreme weather in the U.S. and around the world. Follow here for news on heat waves, wildfires, floods and more.
content: Conditions in and above the Atlantic Ocean continue to suggest that this year’s hurricane season will be an above average one, a government scientist said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: $5,800 Whiskey Bottle, a Gift From Japan to Pompeo, Is Missing, U.S. Says
description: The State Department is investigating what happened to it.
content: The State Department is investigating the whereabouts of a $5,800 bottle of whiskey the Japanese government gave to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in 2019, according to two people briefed on the inquiry and a document made public on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai, Benjamin Mueller, Daniel E. Slotnik and Adeel Hassan
title: The W.H.O. urges wealthy countries to halt booster shots and send more doses to poorer nations.
description: The moratorium, which the agency asked for until the end of September, is an appeal to the world’s wealthiest nations to address dramatic disparities in global vaccination rates.
content: The World Health Organization called on Wednesday for a moratorium on coronavirus vaccine booster shots until the end of September, so that vaccine supplies can be focused on helping all countries vaccinate at least 10 percent of their populations. The agency made its appeal to the world’s wealthiest nations to address the wide disparities in vaccination rates around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo
title: Hopatcong, N.J.: ‘We Call It Lake Life’
description: In this Sussex County borough, where activities revolve around the largest freshwater lake in New Jersey, housing prices have jumped during the pandemic.
content: Hollie Howard discovered Lake Hopatcong while looking out the window of an airplane, en route to Newark Airport five years ago. A search of aerial views of lakes soon revealed that she had been flying over New Jersey’s largest freshwater lake. With a little more research, she learned that the lake was about 40 miles west of New York City, where she was living and performing in Broadway shows.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Exodus of Expertise Under Trump
description: Hundreds of scientists and policy analysts left the government during the last administration. That’s a problem for President Biden’s climate agenda.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s contempt for climate science continues to reverberate, six months into the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: To Jump Higher, Vashti Cunningham Entrusted Her Father. The Quarterback.
description: After an injury, Vashti Cunningham and her father, Randall (yes, that one) came up with a new formula to master the high jump — rarely jumping.
content: TOKYO — There are not a lot of boxes left for Vashti Cunningham to check in the high jump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Defense Secretary Weighs Recommending Vaccine Mandate for Troops
description: His decision is expected in the next few days. But it will ultimately be up to the president, who must grant a waiver to the Defense Department.
content: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III will decide in the next few days whether to recommend that President Biden make coronavirus vaccinations mandatory for the country’s 1.3 million active-duty troops, military officials said, signaling a major move by the administration to harden the country’s defenses against the highly contagious Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Cecily Strong Is Starting a New Conversation
description: The “Saturday Night Live” star shares the story of her pandemic experience and a life touched by grief in “This Will All Be Over Soon.”
content: RHINEBECK, N.Y. — It’s hard to think of Cecily Strong and not be reminded of the effusive television characters she plays. If you’re a “Saturday Night Live” fan, you immediately conjure up her exuberant performance as a soused Jeanine Pirro crooning “My Way” while she dunks herself in a tank of wine. Or if you’ve been watching her on the Apple TV+ musical comedy “Schmigadoon!,” you think of her belting out modern-day show tunes praising the pleasures of corn pudding or smooching with a suitor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Obama Significantly Scales Back 60th Birthday Party as Virus Cases Rebound
description: Hundreds of former Obama administration officials, celebrities and Democratic donors had been planning to attend the huge bash on Martha’s Vineyard on Saturday.
content: WASHINGTON — The party plans had been months in the making and many invitees had already arrived on Martha’s Vineyard when former President Barack Obama belatedly announced he was canceling his huge 60th birthday bash scheduled for Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Is working from home working for you?
description: Tell us about your remote-work experience.
content: Since the pandemic upended life last year, workdays for many of us who have been told to avoid the office have been very different. Some of it has been positive, allowing us to spend more time with our loved ones instead of commuting. Sometimes we work from our couch, or take calls from picnic blankets in the park or log into a meeting from our parents’ house. Other times, remote work can feel isolating, and Zoom fatigue can leave us feeling depleted and unfulfilled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Coming of Age in 2021: A Multimedia Contest for Teenagers
description: An invitation to show us — in words or images, audio or video — how you and your generation are being shaped by these extraordinary times. Contest Dates: Sept. 15-Oct. 27, 2021
content: The world is slowly beginning to emerge from a crisis that has challenged and changed all of us. Who are you now? How do you think the last year and a half has shaped — and will continue to shape — you and your generation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: The police officer killed in the Pentagon attack and his assailant are identified.
description: Officer George Gonzalez, a Brooklyn native, had previously served with the U.S. Army in Iraq.
content: ARLINGTON, Va. — The Defense Department identified George Gonzalez on Wednesday as the police officer killed in Tuesday’s attack at the Pentagon’s Metro bus platform. Officer Gonzalez, 37, was a native of Brooklyn and had been a Pentagon police officer since 2018, according to a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Sussman Fischler
title: House Hunting in Montenegro: A Bayside Villa With Mountain Scenery
description: Along the Balkan nation’s Adriatic coastline, sales are spiking and prices are returning to 2019 levels, with demand outpacing construction.
content: This semidetached, four-bedroom stone villa is in Lepetane, a coastal village just north of the town of Tivit, in southwest Montenegro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Dana Rubinstein and Brian M. Rosenthal
title: 5 Things to Know About the Cuomo Sexual Harassment Findings
description: The report issued Tuesday by the New York State attorney general, Letitia James, could make it difficult for the governor to remain in office.
content: Andrew M. Cuomo’s future as the governor of New York is in doubt after the state attorney general released a report on Tuesday that found that he had sexually harassed 11 women, including nine current and former employees, in violation of state and federal law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: Let the Wedding Come to You
description: Couples interested in a mobile wedding, whether it’s a traditional church affair or a Pinterest-worthy bash, now have a number of options.
content: On a recent sunny day in June, a wedding chapel hit the road. It was just another day for the chapel on wheels, which brings the wedding to your front door — wherever that may be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: 9 Charged With Trafficking Dozens of Guns to New York From Georgia
description: Amid increased federal attention to gun violence, officials announced a bust that they said included the seizure of a weapon used to shoot at the police.
content: The guns were bought from legitimate dealers in Georgia before being brought north, making their way to New York City by bus and rental car, as traffickers concealed their cargo and referred to the firearms with code names, the authorities said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Stravinsky
description: Dive into the composer who changed music history and gave Mikhail Baryshnikov “my first heady sniff of the West.”
content: In the past, we’ve chosen the five minutes or so we would play to make our friends fall in love with classical music, piano, opera, cello, Mozart, 21st-century composers, violin, Baroque music, sopranos, Beethoven, flute, string quartets, tenors, Brahms, choral music, percussion and symphonies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Here’s what happened in Tokyo on Wednesday.
description: The U.S. women’s basketball team easily won its semifinal, Andre de Grasse of Canada won gold in the 200 meters, and U.S. baseball beat the Dominican Republic to reach the semifinals.
content: TOKYO — Sydney McLaughlin needed a world record of 51.46 seconds to beat her fellow American and rival Dalilah Muhammad in the 400 hurdles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Brodsky
title: I’m a Civil Rights Lawyer. Cuomo Got His Due.
description: The governor wanted due process. The facts uncovered by that process are devastating.
content: When Gov. Andrew Cuomo first faced allegations of sexual harassment, many New York politicians were ready to impeach him. But other officials, and many voters, insisted they could not judge before a thorough and official investigation. Mr. Cuomo deserved due process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Facing Loss of Supporters, Cuomo Gains Attention From Prosecutors
description: District attorneys in Manhattan, Nassau, Oswego and Westchester Counties separately announced that they were investigating Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s actions.
content: A day after the release of a devastating report concluding that he had sexually harassed 11 women, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo found himself increasingly isolated on Wednesday, with his most loyal supporters abandoning him and four prosecutors saying they would investigate his behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: A New Improv Theater Tries to Be the Anti-U.C.B. Is That a Trap, Too?
description: A diverse board of comics is trying to build an inclusive, accessible institution. But knowing what they don’t want to be may not be enough.
content: When the Upright Citizens Brigade permanently closed its New York operations last year, the news hit Corin Wells like a death in the family. She moved to the city because of U.C.B., invested time and money, evolving from a student to a teacher and in the uncertain early months of the pandemic, the theater represented an anchor to the past and hope for the future. “When I got the email, I cried,” she said in a video call. “I didn’t have anything to go back to.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Britain will extend vaccination to 16- and 17-year-olds.
description: The nation, which has not been vaccinating young people without underlying conditions, altered its approach after balancing “potential benefits and harms.”
content: Britain is expanding its vaccination campaign to include 16- and 17-year-olds with no underlying health conditions on the advice of the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunization, an independent body responsible for advising its health departments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Younger people are filling hospitals.
content: Doctors working in Covid-19 hot spots across the nation say that the patients in their hospitals are not like the patients they saw last year: The new arrivals are younger, many in their 20s or 30s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Yu Young Jin
title: I.O.C. seeks answers after two Chinese athletes wore Mao pins during the medal ceremony.
description: The red and gold pins were a potential violation of the Olympic charter, which bans “political, religious or racial propaganda” at venues.
content: The International Olympic Committee said it was investigating a potential breach of Olympic regulations after two cyclists from China wore pins bearing the silhouette of Mao Zedong in a medal ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Elsie Chen
title: After Months as a Covid Success Story, China Tries to Tame Delta
description: The government has imposed lockdowns and is testing and tracing aggressively to fight a new outbreak. Experts say it is time for the country to rethink its approach to the virus.
content: In the battle against the coronavirus, few places seemed as confident of victory as China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Democratic Insider and a Republican Backed by Trump Win Ohio House Races
description: The victories by Shontel Brown, a Democrat supported by the national establishment, and Mike Carey, a Republican endorsed by Donald Trump, provided a lift to the leadership of both parties.
content: A Democratic candidate backed by the party establishment and a Republican endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump won two primary races for open House seats in Ohio on Tuesday, an assertion of dominance for the leadership of both political parties as they face questions over unity in their ranks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: The Making of an Olympian
description: The best world-class athletes often dabble in a range of sports when young before rising to the top of their game in one, a new analysis found.
content: The world’s top athletes, including Olympians, rarely start competing at a young age or specialize early in the sport that will make them champions, according to a provocative new study of the athletic backgrounds of thousands of successful athletes. Instead, the study finds, most world champions sample one sport after another as children and gain mastery in their chosen activities considerably later than other, more focused young athletes whom they eventually go on to defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah A. Topol
title: Is Taiwan Next?
description: In Taipei, young people like Nancy Tao Chen Ying watched as the Hong Kong protests were brutally extinguished. Now they wonder what’s in their future.
content: Under the sharp light of Taiwan’s Taoyuan International Airport, the 19-year-old was easy to find. He stood alone where Nancy Tao Chen Ying had instructed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden administration has plans to require most foreign visitors to be vaccinated.
description: Officials say the new policy is being readied in the event the United States eases its current travel rules, something that is not predicted to occur soon.
content: The Biden administration is developing plans to require all foreign travelers to the United States to be vaccinated against Covid-19, with limited exceptions, according to an administration official with knowledge of the developing policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: A Toddler Detective, Pirate Parents and Other Witty Treats in Simon Rich’s ‘New Teeth’
description: Rich’s latest collection is again fueled by his antic imagination and skill at moving from absurdity to reality and back.
content: “Listen to this,” I said to the person I live with, waving Simon Rich’s latest book of short stories, “New Teeth,” in the air. It was bedtime. He put down his own book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Is Hollywood Doing Fine With Oklahoma?
description: The Matt Damon film “Stillwater” is one of the rare times that the state gets some degree of a movie spotlight.
content: There’s a moment early in the new Matt Damon drama “Stillwater” that made me both proud and a little disappointed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Col. Dave Severance, Commander at Iwo Jima, Dies at 102
description: He sent Marines to the top of Mount Suribachi to plant the flag. Captured in a photograph, the scene remains an enduring image of American men at war.
content: Col. Dave Severance, the commander of the Marine company that raised a huge American flag over the Japanese island of Iwo Jima in World War II, inspiring the photograph that thrilled the American home front and became an enduring image of men at war, died on Monday at his home in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The Instant Summer Blueprint
description: Tomatoes and “Meatballs.”
content: Welcome. Cold peach soup. “Under the Boardwalk.” The smell of chlorine. Spitting watermelon seeds off the porch into the yard. So much limeade and lemonade (homemade, if possible). Last week, I asked you what would go on your “instant summer” list, what sounds and scents and activities conjure the season for you, no matter the time or place. The tide of responses was a delight: remembrances of summers long past, sun-soaked snapshots unfaded. Here are some of the highlights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $500,000 Homes in New Hampshire, New Jersey and North Dakota
description: A two-bedroom condo in a Tudor Revival mansion in Salem, a former church in Ringoes and a Queen Anne Victorian in Fargo.
content: Edward Francis Searles (1841-1920), an interior designer in northeastern Massachusetts, inherited a fortune from his wife, Mary, the widow of the San Francisco railway magnate Mark Hopkins. He built several large homes in New England, including this one, Stillwater Manor, which crowned a gentleman farm developed just north of Methuen, Mass., where he was born, raised, buried and reburied (after his corpse was exhumed to investigate suspected arsenic poisoning). Designed by Henry Vaughan, the architect of the Washington National Cathedral and parts of the Cathedral of Saint John the Divine, in New York City, the 21-room house was converted into six condominiums in the late 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: Will We Ever Change the Constitution Again?
description: A meaningful new amendment hasn’t been passed in 50 years, and there is no prospect of reform anytime soon.
content: The 26th Amendment to the Constitution took effect 50 years ago this summer, extending the right to vote to all Americans age 18 and older. It was the fourth amendment in the span of a decade, three of which expanded voting rights — a burst of democratic reform nearly unequaled in the nation’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Carney
title: This Summer’s Dance MVP: The Weatherman
description: At Jacob’s Pillow, with all shows outdoors, a new uncontrollable element emerged: weather. That’s where Paul Caiano comes in.
content: BECKET, Mass. — A week after the Jacob’s Pillow season opened here, five dancers were rehearsing in the vegetable garden for a site-specific work, “Tillers of the Soil.” They tied up tomato plants, practiced wielding a machete and learned about the Native planting practice known as three sisters — growing corn, beans and squash together. The sky was clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: In String of Wins, ‘Biden Democrats’ See a Reality Check for the Left
description: Progressives are holding their own with moderates in fights over policy. But off-year elections suggest they need a new strategy for critiquing President Biden without seeming disloyal.
content: Nina Turner, the hard-punching Bernie Sanders ally who lost a special election for Congress in Ohio this week, had unique political flaws from the start. A far-left former state legislator, Ms. Turner declined to endorse Hillary Clinton over Donald J. Trump in 2016. Last year, she described voting for President Biden as a grossly unpalatable option.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Young adults and the virus.
content: Many doctors on the front lines say that in recent months, unvaccinated patients in their 20s and 30s have become more severely ill from the coronavirus, and more quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Shalini Venugopal Bhagat
title: Why India Struggles to Win Olympic Gold
description: The government has overhauled an athletic system that was once underfunded and corrupt, but the pressure to perform weighs on competitors.
content: TOKYO — On Wednesday, in a sumo wrestling hall where women are not normally allowed to enter the ring, Lovlina Borgohain punched for all the girls out there. She jabbed for her far-flung home state of Assam, known for its fine tea but also for an armed insurgency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hahna Yoon
title: Tracing Freedom to a Pair of Jeans
description: For these North Korean defectors, the road to liberty was paved in denim.
content: Last May, in one of those reports that seemed both unbelievable and yet too tantalizing to ignore, there was a flurry of excitement in numerous Western newspapers over the supposed news that Kim Jong-un, the autocratic ruler of North Korea, had issued an official edict banning ripped or skinny jeans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: P.P.P. loan forgiveness portal opens, but big banks opt out.
description: Several lenders said they preferred to stick with their own processes out of concern that steering customers to the government portal would create confusion.
content: In an effort to speed forgiveness of Paycheck Protection Program loans, the government on Wednesday opened an online portal through which small businesses that borrowed up to $150,000 can apply to have their loans eliminated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
title: Beware Free Wi-Fi: Government Urges Workers to Avoid Public Networks
description: The National Security Agency warned government employees that hackers could take advantage of the public Wi-Fi in coffee shops, airports and hotel rooms.
content: The Biden administration would like you to get a vaccine and wear a mask. Oh, and one more thing: It has just proclaimed that it’s time for government employees and contractors to get off public Wi-Fi, where they can pick up another kind of virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: 50 Years of Taking Photography Seriously
description: When the Photographers’ Gallery opened in London in 1971, few saw the medium as suitable for exhibitions. Today, everyone does.
content: LONDON — In 1968, Sue Davies was working as a secretary at the Institute of Contemporary Arts in the British capital when a colleague got sick, and she found herself left to finish off a photography show they had been working on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: After earning a bronze medal, Noah Lyles opens up about mental health and the challenges of the past year.
description: A tearful Lyles, like many athletes at the Games, spoke about the burdens of performing in a period shadowed by the pandemic and racial strife — and a yearlong postponement of the Games themselves.
content: TOKYO — Noah Lyles, the American sprinting star, was less than an hour removed from racing to a bronze medal in the men’s 200 meters at the Tokyo Games on Wednesday when he opened up about his mental health and the challenges he had faced over the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel and Reed Abelson
title: Nursing Homes Confront New Covid Outbreaks Amid Calls for Staff Vaccination Mandates
description: With the vaccinated elderly susceptible to breakthrough infections, inoculation of workers is becoming more urgent.
content: In late spring, the 142 nursing homes operated by the Good Samaritan Society hit a milestone that was unthinkable just four months earlier: Zero cases of Covid-19 across the whole company, from 900 at the peak of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo and Kellen Browning
title: New York City’s Vaccine Passport Plan Renews Online Privacy Debate
description: The mainstreaming of digital vaccine passes could lead to more surveillance, privacy researchers cautioned.
content: When New York City announced on Tuesday that it would soon require people to show proof of at least one coronavirus vaccine shot to enter businesses, Mayor Bill de Blasio said the system was “simple — just show it and you’re in.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phil Coffin
title: The mother of Raven Saunders, shot-put silver medalist, dies.
description: Clarissa Saunders had been in Orlando, Fla., for a watch party for her daughter’s competition in the Tokyo Games, NBC reported.
content: On Sunday, Raven Saunders won a silver medal in the shot-put at the Tokyo Games. On Tuesday, NBC reported that her mother had died in Orlando, Fla., where she had gone to attend an Olympic watch party for her daughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Here’s How You Can Show Proof of Vaccination in New York City
description: There are two official apps, the Excelsior Pass and NYC Covid Safe, but paper is fine too.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s announcement on Tuesday that people participating in indoor activities at restaurants, gyms, movie theaters and performances in New York City must soon show proof of vaccination for the coronavirus brought a slew of questions from New Yorkers: How can I show vaccination status? Which vaccine app is best? What if I lost my card? What if I got vaccinated in another country?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Digging Into a Dispute Over a Company Entrusted With Art
description: The Artist Pension Trust was created to pool, store and sell the works of painters and sculptors. After it drew complaints from many of those clients, two reporters set out to learn more.
content: ​​The story started with the artists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Spiers
title: How Cuomo Got Away With It for So Long
description: For years, the New York governor played the tough guy. And people bought his act.
content: There’s a frequently recurring narrative that plays out when a public figure is accused of sexual harassment: a chorus of defenders inevitably emerges to assert that the accused is actually a nice guy, historically respectful of women, and where applicable, has daughters who don’t appear to loathe him. Some of these defenders point out that the accused treated them well and never harassed them personally, as if that detracts from the credibility of the allegations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Patricia Kennealy-Morrison, Rock Journalist, Dies at 75
description: She took the music seriously at a time when not many writers did. Among her books was a memoir of her life with one of its biggest stars, Jim Morrison.
content: Patricia Kennealy-Morrison, who wrote about rock when music journalists were just beginning to take it seriously, and through her work met Jim Morrison, frontman of the Doors, with whom she said she had a marriage of sorts, died on July 23. She was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Isabella Kwai
title: World’s Coronavirus Infection Total Passes Staggering Figure: 200 Million
description: Vaccines have weakened the link between surging cases and serious illness, but in vaccine-deprived parts of the world, the deadly pattern remains.
content: Two hundred million is an enormous number.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Resurgence of Policy Protests
description: Some are sparked by tragedy, some are born out of strategy.  Both are needed.
content: On Saturday, The Poor People’s Campaign, Black Lives Matter, Beto O’Rourke and other activists concluded a 27-mile Selma-to-Montgomery-style march in Texas from Georgetown to the State Capitol in Austin, in part to protest attempts in Texas to pass restrictive voting laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: A wildfire in Greece burned dozens of homes amid a searing heat wave.
description: Thousands of people were forced to evacuate on Tuesday, including many who had to be rescued by firefighters.
content: ATHENS — Greek firefighters on Wednesday were working to put out a blaze that broke out on Tuesday on forestland north of Athens, burning dozens of homes and turning large swaths of land to ash, with similar efforts underway to douse wildfires in the southern Peloponnese peninsula and other parts of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Booming Interest in Boating Leads to More Deaths and Accidents
description: The U.S. Coast Guard reported a 25 percent jump in boating fatalities last summer compared to the year before. Casualty numbers this summer are tracking to be even higher.
content: David Beek knows the waterways in Newport Beach, Calif., better than anyone. His family has owned and operated the Balboa Island Ferry, a commuter boat for both cars and people, for more than 100 years. And from his perch on the ferry’s fuel dock, he can see everything that’s happening in Newport Harbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Japan Grabs the First 3 Skateboarding Golds
description: A park competition with lip tricks, grabs and aerial spin ends with gold for Sakura Yosozumi of Japan and more youthful celebrating at the Tokyo Games.
content: TOKYO — The formidable team of skateboarders from Japan continued their stellar performance at the Olympics, and on Wednesday combined to end the gold medal hopes of 13-year-old Sky Brown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: U.S. broadcast coverage on Wednesday morning includes diving, track and beach volleyball.
description: Spain also plays France in the women’s basketball quarterfinals, with the loser eliminated from medal contention.
content: Here are highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage on Wednesday morning. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Oscar Lopez
title: Mexico Sues Gun Companies in U.S., Accusing Them of Fueling Violence
description: The government accuses gun makers and suppliers of knowingly flooding the market with firearms attractive to drug cartels.
content: MEXICO CITY — For years, Mexican officials have complained that lax U.S. gun control was responsible for devastating bloodshed in Mexico. On Wednesday, they moved their campaign into American courts, filing a lawsuit against 10 gun companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: ‘Vaccinated or You Can’t Come In’
description: The latest corporate vaccine mandates cover more types of workers — and customers.
content: The federal government continues to pressure private companies to introduce coronavirus vaccine mandates to help the U.S. raise its inoculation rates. To make it easier, the F.D.A. is accelerating its timetable to fully approve the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, aiming to complete the process early next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Knicks May Not Be Dreaming Big Enough
description: The Knicks had a good season — but good enough to just run it back? It doesn’t seem like it, and yet that appears to be their strategy.
content: Imagine you own a brand-name company with a beloved product. For decades, because of poor design decisions, the company has released versions of the product that have gone over poorly with customers — think Coca-Cola Bacon. But you put a new leadership team in place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Black Man Who Says He Was Threatened With Noose Now Faces Charges Himself
description: “There’s nothing more American than charging a Black man in his own attempted lynching,” Vauhxx Booker of Indiana said of the charges against him, which he sees as retaliation from the special prosecutor.
content: Last summer, a video of a white man pinning a Black man to a tree near a lake in Indiana on July 4 — as bystanders urge the white man and his friends to let the man go — generated national outrage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Elaine Thompson-Herah was temporarily blocked from posting to Instagram after sharing videos of her races.
description: A spokesperson for the company said the Jamaican sprinter’s access to her account was mistakenly suspended.
content: Jamaica’s Elaine Thompson-Herah, who made history in Tokyo by becoming the first woman to win gold in the 100 and 200 meters in consecutive Games, was temporarily blocked from posting to Instagram on Tuesday afternoon after sharing a video of her Olympic races.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Museums and Gardens and Koi (Oh, My!)
description: Plenty of art, of course. But also electrifying parties and, yes, hypnotic fish.
content: Whenever I have a day off and nothing planned, I like to take myself out for a museum day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Gilbert V. Levin, Who Said He Found Signs of Life on Mars, Dies at 97
description: Most planetary scientists dismissed his conclusions, but he remained steadfast that the experiment he conducted in the mid-1970s had been a success.
content: Gilbert V. Levin, whose experiment on NASA’s Viking mission in the 1970s seemed to suggest that there might be life in the soil of Mars, died on July 26 at a hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Assassination Mastermind May Still Be at Large, Haiti’s Caretaker Leader Says
description: Prime Minister Ariel Henry says he believes that none of the more than 40 people detained in the killing of President Jovenel Moïse have the capacity to organize the complex plot.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The mastermind behind the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti is most likely still at large, the country’s caretaker leader says. He remains baffled by the motive, he says, and he doubts that the conspirators accused of plotting the killing had the ability to pull it off on their own.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 3 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: JoAnn Verburg’s olive trees, captured on three continents; Joshua Marsh’s new landscape paintings; and Cameron Spratley’s collage paintings.
content: The images of olive trees in California, Israel, and Italy that make up “For Now,” JoAnn Verburg’s current show at Pace, are resplendent, enigmatic, and a kind of feint; Verburg’s real subject is time and how it’s experienced. The multiple frame photography and video works, lavishly textured and devotionally rendered, operate as Delphic objects, portals to nature. Of course, a climate-controlled gallery is far away from nature, but the power of Verburg’s images is such that even if they don’t exactly transport you to the stillness of the Umbrian countryside, you feel like they could, and the small gravity between those ideas is momentarily erased.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Carl Heastie: The Man Who Would Oversee Cuomo’s Impeachment
description: The Democratic Assembly speaker, most comfortable behind the scenes, now finds himself in the spotlight, facing the possibility of taking down a governor from his own party.
content: President Biden’s call for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York to resign after a state investigation found he had sexually harassed 11 women sparked a flurry of breaking news alerts on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Friday Night Footlights: How Theater Bonds a Colorado Town
description: Silver mining may have disappeared, but Creede Repertory Theater has been an economic and cultural boon to its community for 50 years.
content: CREEDE, Colo. — Perched at 8,900 feet in the San Juan Mountains, five hours from the nearest major airport and near the Rio Grande headwaters, Creede is a town of around 350 full-time residents, with one grocery store, one gas station and a fast-rushing flume. A traffic light? Now you’re asking for a lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorie Greenspan
title: These Strawberry Mini-Cakes Are Perfect Party Food
description: A first birthday calls for these small tender confections, just right for chubby baby hands.
content: Almost a year ago, Gemma Tao Greenspan was born, and I became a grandmother. I also became the person you couldn’t trust to remember a thing about her own child’s life. When my daughter-in-law, Linling Tao, called to ask when Joshua, my son and her husband, first slept through the night, I didn’t know the answer and couldn’t guess at it. First step? I think it was 11 months. First real food? I don’t remember. I hope it wasn’t cookies, but it might have been. I remember that he did a terrific imitation of a flamingo at 15 months — I know this because we recorded it on our video camera, which weighed almost as much as I did. But did he like green beans? Cod? Chicken livers? Chicken livers! I never thought to make them for Joshua, but I probably should have — all that iron would have been good for him. Taking care of a baby was so full time, so all-everything for me that I couldn’t imagine I’d ever forget a minute of Joshua’s life. But I was wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The record for the youngest gold medalist stays intact. But who exactly holds that record remains a mystery.
description: Kokona Hiraki, 12, and Sky Brown, 13, won silver and bronze in park skateboard, leaving Marjorie Gestring, a 13-year-old American diver, as the youngest athlete to have won an Olympic gold. But there’s a twist.
content: Kokona Hiraki of Japan, 12, and Sky Brown of Britain, 13, won the silver and bronze medals in the park skateboard competition on Wednesday. Because they didn’t win, they failed to claim the title of youngest-ever Olympic gold medalist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: What if Humans Just Can’t Get Along Anymore?
description: Humanity’s greatest trick is working together. The internet has made that more difficult.
content: At the broadest level, human history is a story about cooperation. Individually, we big-brained, hairless primates are fairly ridiculous creatures, easy pickings for any dad-bod Simba roaming the plains. But get us together and we achieve dominion over land and sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Uber shows signs of pulling out of its pandemic slump.
description: Uber recorded a rare profit of $1.1 billion, thanks to its stake in the Chinese ride-hailing company Didi.
content: Uber is recovering from the pandemic and the driver shortages that followed, the company said on Wednesday. The company’s revenue in the second quarter grew 105 percent from the same period last year, to $3.9 billion, slightly higher than analysts expected. Uber also recorded a rare profit of $1.1 billion, thanks to the initial public offering of the Chinese ride-hailing company Didi, of which Uber owns an 11 percent stake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Kaiser-Schatzlein
title: The Internet Demands Uplifting Videos. So He Stages Them.
description: Dhar Mann and other “wholesome” channels combine the high-definition slickness of today’s YouTube content with the feel of a corporate-training video.
content: Few online genres are as fascinating as the realm of “wholesome” content, an ever-widening pool of tender, morally uplifting stories about moments of kindness, human beings caring for one another and people leaving big tips. Most of this wholesomeness is found in real life, captured in videos of charming family moments or warm encounters with strangers. Other examples are at least manufactured in real life, as with the TikTok influencer who films himself buying things for people living on the streets of Los Angeles. You might think a staged, fictional video of an inspiring moment, clumsily scripted and stiffly acted, would be infinitely less compelling, and yet: Consider the YouTube sensation Dhar Mann and his 11.2 million subscribers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Citing Forced Labor, U.S. Blocks Fishing Boat From Fiji
description: The action was part of a larger Customs crackdown. Officials said the operators withheld workers’ wages, kept their identity documents and subjected them to debt bondage — essentially enslaving them.
content: Customs officials have blocked a commercial fishing boat from bringing tuna and other seafood into the United States, citing what they said was the use of forced labor by its operator, a company based in Fiji.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelsie Snow
title: Parenting Through Terminal Illness
description: As their father fights to live, my children and I learn how to grieve.
content: One night last fall, as I sat in bed with my 9-year-old son, Cohen, he looked up at me through tears and asked, “Do you think Daddy will have a long life or a short life?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Most children recover quickly from Covid, but some have lingering symptoms, a study says.
description: Most children with Covid-19 recover within a week, but a small percentage experience long-term symptoms, according to a new study of more than 1,700 British children. The researchers found that 4.4 percent of children had symptoms that last four weeks or longer, while 1.8 percent have symptoms that last for eight weeks or longer.
content: Most children with Covid-19 recover within a week, but a small percentage experience long-term symptoms, according to a new study of more than 1,700 British children. The researchers found that 4.4 percent of children had symptoms that last four weeks or longer, while 1.8 percent have symptoms that last for eight weeks or longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The U.S. baseball team beats the Dominican Republic, keeping its gold medal hopes alive.
description: The former M.L.B. All-Star Scott Kazmir, 37, pitched five scoreless innings in the Americans’ 3-1 win. The U.S. plays South Korea next.
content: YOKOHAMA, Japan — Behind one of its oldest and one of its youngest players, the United States toppled the Dominican Republic, 3-1, on Wednesday to advance to the semifinals and preserve its gold medal hopes. The U.S., which last won the Olympics’ top prize in 2000, will face South Korea on Thursday, with the chance to face unbeaten Japan in the final on the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Why Covid Took Off in California, Again
description: Wednesday: Not enough Californians are vaccinated to stop the spread of the Delta variant. Plus, how to stay safe from infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Taliban Claim Responsibility for Major Attack in Afghan Capital
description: The hourslong raid, which killed eight people, targeted a top military official’s home near Kabul’s fortified green zone.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban claimed responsibility on Wednesday for an attack on the home of a top military official in Kabul that killed eight people, highlighting the insurgents’ ability to strike in the heart of the Afghan capital as they continue their sweeping military campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Booster Shots, Hurricane Season, Karate: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Abebech Gobena, the ‘Mother Teresa’ of Africa, Dies at 85
description: She created one of Ethiopia’s largest orphanages and through it saved thousands from starvation and disease. She died of complications of Covid-19.
content: Abebech Gobena was returning from a pilgrimage to the holy site of Gishen Mariam, about 300 miles north of the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa, when she saw the woman and her baby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: CNN’s Cuomo Conundrum: A Star Anchor With a Brother in Trouble
description: Chris Cuomo, the top-rated host, left some colleagues confused after he did not acknowledge the calls for Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s resignation during his Tuesday show.
content: Earlier this year, CNN executives floated an idea to their star anchor Chris Cuomo. If he wanted to formally advise his brother, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, on responding to the sexual harassment accusations that had engulfed his administration, he could take a temporary leave from CNN and return to the network later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Janja Garnbret of Slovenia leads the qualifiers in women’s sport climbing.
description: Garnbret, the most dominating competition climber of recent years and the gold medal favorite, cruised into the eight-woman final with a typically strong performance.
content: TOKYO — Janja Garnbret of Slovenia, the most dominating competition climber of recent years and the gold medal favorite in the first Olympic women’s sport climbing competition, cruised into the eight-woman final with a typically strong performance on Wednesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Shontel Brown’s Ascent Gives Democratic Establishment a Victory
description: Ms. Brown, who defeated the progressive activist Nina Turner in a bitter Democratic primary for an Ohio House seat, is all but assured of heading to Congress in the fall.
content: Shontel Brown campaigned for an open House seat in the Cleveland area declaring that she would be “a partner,” not an adversary, of President Biden and Speaker Nancy Pelosi. And now that she is almost guaranteed to join them in Washington after her victory on Tuesday in a contentious Democratic primary, Ms. Brown’s history suggests that party leaders will be adding a loyal political insider to their team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Herrman
title: Twitter Is Stuck With Itself, Too
description: The most stubborn social network admits defeat, retires Fleets.
content: It was just another Wednesday morning on the timeline, but something was off. Everyone was posting. They seemed a little stressed, but that’s normal. The Greenwich Mean fights were dispersing. Eastern Standard discourses were shuffling into formation. Main character auditions were underway. All of the little mixed-metaphor icons — the birdhouse, the magnifying glass, the bell, the envelope, the quill (?) with a plus sign (??) — seemed to be in order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: What to Watch in the Sport Climbing Finals at the Olympics
description: Adam Ondra and Janja Garnbret, two of the world’s best climbers, are in the men’s and women’s finals, but can they succeed under the event’s quirky scoring system?
content: In sport climbing’s first appearance at the Olympics, eight men and eight women have advanced to the finals, scheduled for Thursday and Friday in Tokyo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Biden’s Honeymoon Is Over, and He Knows It
description: As he faces multiple crises, has the value of his political experience been underestimated?
content: The first seven months of the Biden presidency have been easy compared with what’s coming down the pike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Dimon
title: If You Paid Your Debt to Society, You Should Be Allowed to Work
description: Americans who were incarcerated or have a conviction on their record are largely locked out of the economy. This moral outrage must end.
content: One in three American adults — more than 70 million people — have some type of criminal record. To put this in perspective, about the same number of Americans have college degrees right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Sydney McLaughlin won the 400-meter hurdles, defeating the 2016 Olympic champion, Dalilah Muhammad of the U.S.
description: McLaughlin won with a time of 51.46 seconds, a new world record.
content: TOKYO — Sydney McLaughlin recently said that “iron sharpens iron” when it comes to her relationship with Dalilah Muhammad. They are the pre-eminent practitioners of their craft, the two fastest women ever to run the 400-meter hurdles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Matthew Cullen
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Delta puts China to the test.
content: Months after China was hailed as a success story in curbing the coronavirus, the country is facing its biggest challenge since the virus first emerged in Wuhan: The highly infectious Delta variant is now rapidly spreading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: The C.D.C. Needs to Stop Confusing the Public
description: The C.D.C. isn’t following its own guidance to “be first, be right, be credible.”
content: “Be first, be right, be credible,” are among the most important principles for health authorities to follow in a crisis, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shared in a pamphlet on crisis communication in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: The U.S. women’s basketball team routed Australia to reach the semifinals.
description: The United States ran its Olympic winning streak to 53 straight games.
content: Breanna Stewart scored 23 points to lead the United States to a 79-55 rout of Australia in the women’s basketball quarterfinals in Saitama, Japan, moving one step closer to the team’s seventh consecutive Olympic gold medal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Gig companies want Massachusetts voters to exempt workers from employee status.
description: The ballot proposal mirrors an initiative that the companies proposed last year in California. They ultimately prevailed in exempting their workers from a law that would have effectively classified them as employees.
content: A coalition of gig economy companies that includes Uber, Lyft, DoorDash and Instacart said on Wednesday that it had filed a ballot proposal in Massachusetts that could create a new class of workers in the commonwealth. If the coalition is successful, Massachusetts voters will decide next year whether gig workers should be considered independent contractors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Senate panel votes to repeal 1991 and 2002 laws authorizing wars with Iraq.
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 14-8 to repeal the authorizations. The resolution now goes to the full Senate.
content: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted on Wednesday to repeal the 1991 law that authorized the Persian Gulf War and the 2002 law that authorized President George W. Bush to invade Iraq and topple Saddam Hussein, sending the resolution to the Senate floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: This iconic cactus can stand the heat, but not the wildfires.
description: ORO VALLEY, Ariz. — It began with a flash of lightning, the fire that swept across the rugged Santa Catalina Mountains on Tucson’s edge. By the time firefighters got the blaze under control, it had torched thousands of saguaros, the towering cactuses that can reach heights of 60 feet and live for 200 years.
content: ORO VALLEY, Ariz. — It began with a flash of lightning, the fire that swept across the rugged Santa Catalina Mountains on Tucson’s edge. By the time firefighters got the blaze under control, it had torched thousands of saguaros, the towering cactuses that can reach heights of 60 feet and live for 200 years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Octogenarian Marathoners to a Haunted Southern Plantation Wedding
description: A selection of recently published books.
content: RACING THE CLOCK: Running Across a Lifetime, by Bernd Heinrich. (Ecco, $27.99.) A biologist and marathon runner, the author of “Why We Run” embarks on a 50-kilometer race at age 80 and uses his research and own experiences to examine how our bodies age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: A top Fed official says rate increases could be warranted in 2023.
description: Richard Clarida, the vice chair for monetary policy, said he expected inflation and the unemployment rate to reach the Federal Reserve’s goals by the end of next year.
content: Richard H. Clarida, the Federal Reserve’s vice chair, said in speech on Wednesday that if the economy meets his expectations, he thinks it will be healed enough by the end of next year for the Fed to start raising rates in 2023 — a meaningful statement coming from one of the highest-ranking members of the policy-setting committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Andre De Grasse wins the 200 meters, his second medal at these Games.
description: It’s been a busy night in the Olympic Stadium. Here are some highlights.
content: TOKYO — Andre De Grasse of Canada claimed his second medal of the Tokyo Olympics on Wednesday, sprinting to gold in the men’s 200 meters in 19.62 seconds, a national record.
